How the Adrenal Glands Trigger Menopause Symptoms

Posted 14, April 2019 by
Dr. Dayana Deschamps - 0 min read

Women have significant phases of hormonal changes throughout life starting with puberty, then pregnancy and breastfeeding. Then, just as significantly perimenopause, menopause, and post-menopause. We go from teens to having children and before you know it, menopause hits.

Female hormones govern very specific times of change and they determine so much of how we experience life on a daily basis. Simultaneously, there is another gland in the body that plays a pivotal role in their energy and stress levels, and that is the adrenal gland.

As the hormone levels drop in the ovaries, the adrenal glands help to take over female hormonal production. While at the same time, they continue to produce hormones, such as testosterone, cortisol, and adrenaline. The hormones that give us the drive to wake in the morning; and deal with ongoing stressors of the day. 

The adrenal glands and menopause

The adrenals glands are small glands that are situated near the top of the kidneys. They secrete the hormones cortisol and epinephrine; which are commonly referred to as stress hormones. The cell receptors for both cortisol and epinephrine fluctuate in the body. Depending on how much stimulation they receive by the nervous system.

This is based on several factors, such as long term stress and the use of substances; such as caffeine, alcohol, and sugar. Lack of exercise also play a major role as well as emotions. This can lead to an overactive or underative adrenal. Such problem can contribute to low immunity. The Side effects are as follow:

  • insomnia,
  • moodiness,
  • chronic infections
  • and even immune disorders. As stress builds in the mind and body, so the adrenal glands will suffer.

Healthy adrenal function in the body promotes restful sleep and a sense of wellbeing in the person. They also can have an effect on the thyroid system, which is a key component in regulating things such as hormones and brain activity; blood circulation, calcium balance, tissue maintenance, and even the temperature of the body. A lower thyroid function is somewhat common during perimenopause. It can also cause symptoms of menopause to become much worse if left unchecked.

When the adrenal glands and thyroid are both unbalanced, it can result in a condition called “hypothyroidism”; which symptoms include:

  • fatigue,
  • weight gain,
  • depression and mood swings,
  • cold hands and feet,
  • constipation,
  • severe and frequent hot flashes and/ or night sweats,
  • reduced libido, and sleep disorders.

Is it any wonder that a woman would want to keep these two glands in good condition? Once the hormones are out of balance, the body can react in very unpredictable ways.

How the adrenal glands can trigger early menopause symptoms?

They produce high levels of female hormones as they take over the role from the ovaries. They become the main site of estrogen and progesterone production in the body. This, however, places more demand on the adrenal glands. It can lead to symptoms of adrenal fatigue as well as reduced energy levels; and feeling overwhelmed by daily activities and an inability to cope with daily stressors. Women who are already experiencing adrenal fatigue may go through menopause earlier. They may experience more symptoms than women whose adrenal function is optimal.

Foods for adrenal support

Nutrition is always the key to making sure that the adrenal glands are taken care of. To give you an idea, here are some of the superfoods that provides your adrenals with the nutrients they need:

  • Wheat Germs and Sprouts –

You can add these foods on top of a salad; or any dish that you would like to prepare. So, instead of using just the usual garnish, make use of these ingredients. In order to get the right amount of nutrients. They are known for healing poorly the adrenal glands.

  • Deep Ocean Fish –

They are usually expensive. As they are only caught from the deep section of the ocean. But it is worth it because they are high in Omega 3. Which is a very important for the adrenal glands.

  • Whole Grains –

Fiber is a must for a healthy adrenal gland diet. The carbohydrates found in these grains help add natural energy in the adrenal glands; as well as fight back against unnecessary fatigue.

  • Kelp –

It is known for its pituitary and adrenal gland cleansing properties. It also contains natural iodine which helps prevent disorders targeting the thyroid.

  • Turkey –

It might be surprising for some but turkey is considered a lean protein-rich food. It is actually good for inhibiting the possible development of cancer.

  • Coconut –

Whether the meat itself, the juice, or even the oil, coconut is called the tree of life for nothing. It is very healthy and reduces different risks for body ailments.

  • Flaxseed –

This type of food is also rich in Omega 3 fatty acids not unlike what you would find in Salmon. Omega-3’s helps in the modulation of hormones. It can also boost immune system, IQ, fighting inflammation, and promoting cardiovascular health. This is a great thing to include in your diet anyway; but for adrenal fatigue sufferers, it is essential for a full recovery. Watch my video on Best Way to Use the Omega’s to Fight Hormonal Imbalance.

Best supplements to restore adrenal function

Some of the best supplements for adrenal support

  • Panthothenic Acid: Vitamin B5

B5 is also necessary for the production of the stress hormone cortisol and the sex hormones estrogen and testosterone. People who have adrenal fatigue are often depleting their B5 levels. 

  • P-5-P (1): Vitamin B6

B6 Vitamin is an important nutrient for the production of the neurotransmitters serotonin and dopamine. Which play an important role in mood, sleep, energy, and mental impulse. In addition, B6 is a key part of the body’s ability to manufacture the stress hormones norepinephrine and epinephrine.

  • Vitamin C (2):

This antioxidant is directly related to the production of cortisol in the adrenal cortex. In addition, it strengthens the immune system. It also protects the adrenal tissue from excessive oxidative stress related to the heavy production of adrenal hormones.

Herbs to help balancing the adrenals

  • Borage is also known as star-flower. It is a plant that is used occasionally as a herb. It contains calcium, potassium, and mucilages. It can also help to rejuvenate the adrenal glands; as well as improving blood circulation and certain skin conditions.

  • Ashwagandha (3) is an adaptogen said to be equal to ginseng. It reduces inflammation and helps counteract the effect of certain detrimental fungi. It contains various antioxidants and helps with energy, stamina, and sexual performance.

  • Siberian Ginseng (4) can help support the adrenals. It prevents the release of Corticosteroid Hormones from the adrenal glands in response to stress. it can also prevent to atrophy of the adrenal glands.

A word of Caution

Talk to your doctor or healthcare provider before using any supplement or herb. This article is meant to educate and should not replace any medical advice.

Reference

  • Murray, Michael T. The Encyclopedia of Nutritional Supplements: the essential guide for improving your health naturally. Prima Publishing, Rocklin, California, USA. 1996:117. The author states that vitamin B5 is important for optimal adrenal gland function.
  • Haas, Elson M. Staying Healthy with Nutrition. Celestial Arts, Berkeley, California, USA. 1992:124. The author lists fatigue as one of the possible clinical uses of vitamin B6.
  • Whittaker, J. Research roundup: vitamin C. Health & Healing. 9(10):5, 1999.
  • Linder, M. C. Nutrition and metabolism of vitamins. In: Nutritional Biochemistry and Metabolism, 2nd Edition. Maria C. Linder (editor). Simon & Schuster, Connecticut, USA, 1991:146-147. “Ascorbate is clearly required in the synthesis of biogenic amines in the adrenal medulla. The highest tissue concentrations of this vitamin, by far are in the adrenal medulla (and the central nervous system)”.
  • Sodhi, V. Ashwagandha for rejuvenation. New Editions Healthworld. July/Augusts 1994:54-55.”The author refers to a clinical study undertaken in India in which 70% of people aged 50-59 who used Ashwagandha for 12 months reported increased sexual desire”.
  • Batchelder, H. J. Fatigue fighters. MotherNature.com News & Views Health Journal. 3(13), 2000. Ashwagandha is reported to improve stamina.
  • Mishra, L. C., et al. Scientific basis for the therapeutic use of Withania somnifera (ashwagandha): A review. Alternative Medicine Review. 5(4):334-336, 2000.
